article.title: Interband $π$-like plasmon in silicene grown on silver

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1: What is the main difference between the three silicene overlayers shown?
choices: The size of the unit cell.
The out-of-plane atomic buckling.
The type of atoms in the overlayer.
The orientation of the overlayer relative to the substrate.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2: Which silicene phase on Ag(111) has yet to be reported in existing literature?
choices: The (4×4) phase.
The (2√3×2√3)R30° phase.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3: What additional loss peak is observed in the EL spectrum of the mixed phase silicene on Ag(111) compared to clean Ag(111)?
choices: A loss peak at ~0.7 eV.
A loss peak at ~1.75 eV.
A loss peak at ~3.8 eV.
No additional loss peak is observed.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4: What differentiates the electronic band structure of (3x3) silicene from the other three silicene structures shown?
choices: It has a direct bandgap at the K point.
It lacks Dirac cones at the K point.
It has metallic bands of dominant π character.
It shows a quasilinear π-like dispersion in the first VB and CB at K.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5: What type of electron excitations are associated with the low-energy peaks in the theoretical loss spectra of the silicene systems?
choices: Transitions between the first VB and CB of dominant σ character.
Transitions between the second VB and CB of dominant π character.
Quasivertical electron excitations between the first or second VB and CB.
Horizontal electron excitations between the first VB and CB at the Γ point.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 6: What is the main difference between the dispersive modes observed in the momentum-dependent investigation of the silicene superstructures?
choices: The energy range in which they occur.
The type of electron transitions that assist them.
Their dependence on the direction of momentum transfer.
Their sensitivity to the presence of the Ag substrate.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 7: What conclusion can be drawn from the excellent agreement between the experimental loss spectrum of the mixed phase silicene and the theoretical calculations for (1x1) silicene?
choices: The mixed phase silicene on Ag(111) fully recovers the electronic properties of freestanding silicene.
The interaction with Ag(111) completely destroys the π-like plasmon of the silicene overlayers.
The mixed phase morphology presents a dielectric response that matches the π-like plasmon of ideal silicene.
The presence of a π-like plasmon in the mixed phase confirms the presence of a well-defined Dirac cone structure.
